notes:
1. Concept

The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics deals with thermal equilibrium. It is the basis for the concept of temperature.

The law states:

If two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third one, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.

2. Explanation

Imagine you have three objects: A, B, and C.

  • If you touch object A to object C and no heat flows between them, they are in thermal equilibrium.
  • If you touch object B to object C and no heat flows between them, they are also in thermal equilibrium.
  • The Zeroth Law then tells us that if you touch object A to object B, no heat will flow between them either. They are already in thermal equilibrium with each other.

3. Basis for Temperature

This law is fundamental because it implies the existence of a property called temperature. If two objects are in thermal equilibrium, they have the same temperature. Object C in the example above can be thought of as a thermometer. By showing that A and B are both at the same temperature as C, we know that A and B are at the same temperature as each other without ever having to bring them into contact.

solvedExamples.question: The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics provides the basis for the measurement of which property?
solvedExamples.explanation: The Zeroth Law establishes the concept of thermal equilibrium, which is the foundation for defining and measuring temperature. It allows us to use a third body (a thermometer) to determine if two other bodies are at the same temperature.

solvedExamples.question: If object X is in thermal equilibrium with object Y, and object Y is in thermal equilibrium with object Z, what can be concluded?

options.text: Object X and object Z have the same mass.
Object X and object Z are in thermal equilibrium.
More heat will flow from Z to X than from Y to X.
Object Y is a perfect insulator.

solvedExamples.explanation: This is a direct statement of the Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics. If X and Y have the same temperature, and Y and Z have the same temperature, then X and Z must also have the same temperature, meaning they are in thermal equilibrium.
